results.title: Daisy: the story of a facelift
results.creator_credit: Michael Rubbo, Adam Symansky, Giles Walker and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: In a probing yet playful approach to a sensitive subject, this documentary examines the values that prompt people to alter their looks through cosmetic surgery. Personal accounts from men and women, young and old, who have decided to change their bodies are counterbalanced by comments from professionals who explain the effects of physical appearance on our lives. This film focuses mainly on the experiences of Daisy De Bellefeuille, a frank and feisty woman who decides to counter middle age with a facelift. The film provides us with a front-row seat during a facelift operation, as well as a close-up look of the results. (Awards: Melbourne, New York)

results.title: Dairying in Australia
results.creator_credit: Lilias Fraser, Norman Castle and Fraser Castle Productions
results.brief_description: Shows scenes of milking, grazing of herds, production of hay, use of silage, production of small crops for farm use, fertilizing of pastures, pasteurization, cheese and butter making and export of dairy products.

results.title: Jacques le Fataliste et Son Maitre
results.brief_description:
Jacques, who believes in fate, is involved in an endless argument with his master, who does not, as they journey along retelling the stories of their lives and loves.

Credits: Director, Pierre Cardinal ; photography, Jacques Lemare.
Cast: Marie Dubois, Margo Lion, Alexandre Rignault, Claude Gensac, Madeleine Renaud, Jacques Castelot, Jean Paredes.

results.title: Dairying in Australia
results.brief_description: Shows the work of a typical Victorian dairy farm throughout the year, the bulk handling and processing, distribution and export of dairy products. Filmed on locations at Hunterfield Jersey Stud, Kiewa Milk Supply and Murray Valley Irrigation. Commentary by Roger Climpson.
results.description: Shows the work of a typical Victorian dairy farm throughout the year, the bulk handling and processing, distribution and export of dairy products. Filmed on locations at Hunterfield Jersey Stud, Kiewa Milk Supply and Murray Valley Irrigation. Commentary by Roger Climpson.

results.title: Jacques Henri Lartigue, Peintre et Photographe
results.brief_description:
“If we think of photography as a documentary art, our attention is likely to focus first on images of battle or disaster, deprivation or unrest. Indeed, outside the familiar confines of the family album or the surreal arena of celebrity, archival photographs most powerfully frame gritty realities our eyes might otherwise avoid. Not so with the pictures of Jacques Henri Lartigue (1894-1986), who produced stunning and sophisticated images from the time he was seven years old. Lartigue was in love with motion, and his subjects cars racing, flying machines and glider planes, people jumping, fashionable ladies strolling in the park, vacationers at the seashore and the races embody the exhilaration of movement. Zany and amusing, Lartigue’s work seems a testament to happiness itself, and this book with 126 duotone photos and 16 gatefolds is a fitting celebration of his legacy.” Reference: Vicki Goldberg. ‘Jacques Henri Lartigue, photographer’. Bulfinch Press, 1998.

Credits: Producer, Bernard Meusnier ; director, Francois Reichenbach ; photographer, Francois Reichenbach, Gerard de Battista.
Cast: Interviewees include Michel Tournier, Jean-Michel Folon and Charlotte Rampling.

results.title: Jacka V.C.: a film by Nigel Buesst and Ross Cooper
results.creator_credit: Sunrise Picture Company, Nigel Buesst, Ross Cooper, Australian Film Commission and Swinburne Institute of Technology. Film and Television School
results.brief_description: Albert Jacka was raised in the bush, won Australia’s first VC at Gallipoli, and went on to become the epitome of the Australian front line fighting soldier. No man better personified the archetypical Australian of the early decades of the century. His heroic feats captured the imagination of a generation, yet, today Albert Jacka is almost forgotten. This film is not only his life story but also an insight into Australian identity and history through archival footage.
results.title_for_label: Jacka V.C.: a film by Nigel Buesst and Ross Cooper

results.title: Jacky visits the zoo
results.creator_credit: Mort Ransen, Richard Gilbert and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A tour of the zoo is given considerable momentum as an irate keeper chases Jacky for teasing the animals. The camera catches good close-ups of the zoo’s polar bear, lion, giraffe, elephant, rhinoceros, camel, zebra and finally Jacky, in a cage labelled “Wild Boy.” Piano soundtrack, no dialogue. (Award: Rome)

results.title: Jack Bush, 1909-1977
results.creator_credit: Murray Battle, Rudy Buttignol, Cinema Productions and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: The late Canadian painter, Jack Bush, said he painted “from the belly”. Born in Montreal in 1909, he earned his living as a commercial artist until his work gained recognition in the New York art market in 1968. In an interview he gave before his death, Bush talks about his life, his work, the development of art in Canada over the past 25 years. Exhibitions of his work are shown, in particular a retrospective at which he and his friend Clement Greenberg, noted New York art critic, talk about his paintings.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Murray Battle, Rudy Buttignol, Cinema Productions and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Moi drug Ivan Lapshin = My friend Ivan Lapshin
results.brief_description:
The film opens in the present day, in colour, and the narrator reminisces about his experiences as a nine-year old child living in a provincial Russian town. As the film converts to black and white, the young boy tells of the flat he shared with Ivan, a police chief whose main activity in the cold winter of 1935 was to track down a notorious gang of criminals, but who also finds time to make a clumsy attempt at romance with an actress and to take care of his best friend whose wife has died. A detailed portrait of daily life in a pre-purge Soviet Union, ‘My Friend Ivan Lapshin’ is the director’s autobiographical reminiscence on his childhood, based on the stories of his father. Although the film is framed by the innocent observations of a child, through suggestion the narrative hints at the horrors that would become the norm in Stalinist Russia.

Credits: Director, Alexei Gherman ; writer, Eduard Volodarsky ; photography, Valery Fedosov ; music, Arkady Gagulashvili ; editing, L. Semenovoi.
Cast: Nina Ruslanova, Alexei Zharkov, Andrei Boltnev, Andrei Mironov, Aleksei Zharkov, Z. Adamovich.

results.title: Jacks or better
results.creator_credit: David Geddes, Raymond Hall, John Taylor, George Johnson and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Artist Char Davies’ vision of logging expressed in images celebrating the magnificence of the British Columbia forest. This film challenges the myth that stereotypes loggers as insensitive to the act of felling trees. It leaves its audience mindful of deforestation and of our responsibility to it as a living natural resource.
